title: 114_hr6510
content: The "Save the Children Act of 2016" is the short title of this legislation. Congress expresses its sense through this act. Congress acknowledges the humanitarian crisis faced by Syrian children due to civil war violence and supports the temporary relocation and care of up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees. The government should facilitate the temporary relocation and care of up to 25,000 young Syrian minor children refugees who are orphaned or whose guardians transfer custody to the United States. Efforts should also be made for family reunification or safe relocation back to Syria after a substantial reduction in civil war. The government should facilitate family reunification or safe relocation of young Syrian child refugees to Syria after a sustained reduction in civil war violence and displacement. The Save the Children Program is established under Section 3. The Save the Children Program grants visas to young minor children from Syria aged three to ten to enter and stay in the US until there is a significant reduction in civil war violence and displaced inhabitants. After this, there is a six-month grace period for guardians to be identified before the visas expire. The Save the Children Program grants visas to young minor children from Syria aged three to ten to enter and stay in the US until there is a significant reduction in civil war violence and displaced inhabitants. A Coordinator is established in the Office of Refugee Resettlement to oversee the Program's operations in the United States. Only children with established guardians present to relinquish custody or orphaned children are eligible for the visa. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program in the US, appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has supervisory authority over the program's operations. The Coordinator can appoint additional personnel with approved pay rates, including private citizens or non-Federal Government employees. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program can appoint additional personnel, including private citizens or non-Federal Government employees, to assist in carrying out duties. The Coordinator may request personnel from Federal departments or agencies to detail to the Office on a reimbursable or nonreimbursable basis. The Coordinator will utilize the staff and resources of the Division of Unaccompanied Children's Services for operations. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program utilizes the staff and resources of the Division of Unaccompanied Children's Services for operations, including identifying and resettling young minor children in the United States. The Coordinator of the Save the Children Program works with nongovernmental organizations and government authorities to implement the Program for young minor children in the United States, in line with relevant laws and international agreements. Coordination with key government officials ensures the Program's operations align with domestic security interests. The Coordinator consults with key government officials to ensure the Program's operations align with laws, international agreements, and domestic security interests. The Program aims for family reunification within six months of reduced violence in Syria. The Program in Syria aims for family reunification within six months of reduced violence, with termination contingent on sustained reduction in violence and displaced inhabitants as certified by the Secretary of State. The Program in Syria aims for family reunification within six months of reduced violence, with termination contingent on sustained reduction in violence and displaced inhabitants as certified by the Secretary of State. The Program may be suspended or terminated if the President determines it is necessary for the foreign policy and domestic security interests of the United States. The President can suspend or terminate the Program in Syria based on foreign policy and domestic security interests. Appropriations are authorized for each fiscal year, and funds can be used from the Migration and Refugee Assistance Act. A report must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment detailing the Program's implementation. SEC. 4. TEMPORARY NONIMMIGRANT VISA. The Program shall admit up to 5,000 alien minor children aged three to ten in the first year, and 10,000 more in each of the following two years. Preference will be given to children already in custody outside Syria. A temporary nonimmigrant visa is granted until the Secretary of State certifies a significant reduction in civil war violence and displaced individuals in Syria. The Syrian Civil War Minor Child Protection Act of 2016 allows for the admission of alien minor children aged three to ten from Syria or born in Syria but currently displaced, once the Secretary of State certifies a substantial reduction in civil war violence and displaced individuals in Syria. The Save the Children Act of 2016 allows alien minor children aged three to ten to reside in the United States temporarily. They may remain in the US until the Secretary of State certifies a reduction in civil war violence in Syria. Aliens admitted to the United States under the Save the Children Act of 2016 can stay until the Secretary of State certifies a significant reduction in civil war violence in Syria and a decrease in newly displaced Syrian inhabitants, with a six-month grace period for reunification efforts.
